title: Mariel overlay
name: Mariel overlay
description: Soviet ships being loaded at the Mariel Naval Base in Cuba, Nov 5, 1962. They were removing missiles from the country.

properties.name: Bejucal Nuclear Storage Site
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Bejucal Nuclear Storage Site During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets stored nuclear warheads for R-12 missiles targeted on the United States at an underground bunker on this site. The CIA photographed the site, but ruled it out as a nuclear storage site because of the lack of adequate security. The above photograph, taken by a U.S. Navy plane on October 25, shows that the site was protected by a single security fence.

properties.name: Nuclear storage vans
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Nuclear storage vans During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets used specially configured storage cans to transport their nuclear warheads. The above photograph, taken by a U.S. Navy plane on October 25, 1962, shows the vans parked outside an underground bunker near the town of Bejucal. Click on Vans overlay to see their precise location on this date.

properties.name: Soviet headquarters
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Soviet Nuclear Storage HQ During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets stored nuclear warheads near Bejucal. Photographed by a U.S. Navy Crusaader on October 25, 1962, this site was the administrative headquarters for the unit responsible for the warhead facility, commanded by Colonel Romanov. Both the bunker and the HQ facility were protected by Cuban anti-aircraft guns.

properties.name: Bejucal
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Bejucal Nuclear Storage Site During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets stored nuclear warheads for R-12 missiles targeted on the United States near the town of Bejucal. I took this photograph during a visit to Bejucal in 2006. Click on other links to find the nuclear storage site.

properties.name: Managua Nuclear Storage Site
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Managua Nuclear Storage Site During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets stored nuclear warheads for Luna (American designation FROG) missiles at this site. The CIA photographed the site in October 1962, but ruled it out as a nuclear storage site because of the lack of adequate security. Warheads for the R-12 missiles that could hit the United States were stored near Bejucal.

properties.name: Mariel
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Soviets leave Mariel During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets used Mariel as a transit point for nuclear warheads. The warheads were brought to Mariel on board the Indigirka on October 4. This photograph, taken on November 5, 1962, shows nuclear warhead vans lining up on the dock at Mariel to board a Soviet freighter. The warheads were stored at Bejucal, south of Havana.

properties.name: La Isabela
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Nuclear warheads in La Isabela During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets were forced to use the La Isabela as a storage place for nuclear warheads. The warheads were on board the freighter Aleksandrovsk, which was heading for Mariel on October 22, 1962, when John F. Kennedy announced a naval blocade. Khrushchev ordered the ship to put into "the nearest port," together with its sister ship, the Almetyevsk.

properties.name: Severomorsk
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Nuclear warheads in Severomorsk During the Cuban missile crisis, the Soviets shipped nuclear warheads to Cuba through the port of Severomorsk, in order to avoid the chokepoints of the Bosphorus and the Baltic Sea. The warheads left Severomorsk on October 6 on board the 5400-ton freighter Aleksandrovsk. The Swedish-built ship arrived in Cuban waters on October 22, the day that President Kennedy announced the naval. Khrushchev ordered the ship to put into "the nearest port," La Isabela.

properties.name: Sagua La Grande
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Nuclear warheads in Sagua La Grande On October 27, 1962, the tensest day of the Cuban missile crisis, a convoy of nuclear warheads arrived here from the central Soviet nuclear storage depot at Bejucal. They could have been mounted on R-12 missiles and fired at the United States within 120 minutes. The missiles were targeted on New York and Washington. Soviet commanders ordered the warheads dispersed because they feared that the U.S. was about to attack Cuba.
